snippet: For activists anticipating the 2016 presidential race, the minimum wage fight, and the challenge it poses to a system they say favors the rich, comes at a pivotal time.
abstract: Protest in more than 200 American cities by fast-food and other low-wage workers for $15-an-hour minimum wage has broad public support but is up against hostile business sector; issue is timely one, as 2016 presidential election is gearing up and it could become first large-scale challenge to an economic system that some see as favoring the wealthy; while many large employers have moved to raise base pay, business groups claim higher wages will lead to less hiring.

byline.contributor: C. J. Hughes contributed reporting from New York, Ronnie Cohen from San Francisco and Julie Weed from Seattle.

lead_paragraph: For activists anticipating the 2016 presidential race, the minimum wage fight, and the challenge it poses to a system they say favors the rich, comes at a pivotal time.

headline.main: In Test for Unions and Politicians, a Nationwide Protest on Pay
headline.print_headline: In Test for Unions and Politicians, a Nationwide Protest on Pay
